dermatological_conditions.name: Acne Keloidalis
dermatological_conditions.description: Acne keloidalis nuchae is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the posterior neck and occipital scalp, primarily in Black men.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Small, dome-shaped papules and pustules that progress to larger keloid-like nodules and plaques. The lesions appear as firm, flesh-colored to hyperpigmented bumps that may coalesce into larger masses. Hair follicles are typically destroyed, leading to permanent hair loss in affected areas.
symptoms: Small, firm bumps on the back of the neck
Permanent hair loss in affected areas
advice: Avoid close shaving and use electric clippers instead
Keep the neck area clean and dry
Seek early treatment to prevent progression
Be patient as treatment takes time to show results

dermatological_conditions.name: Alopecia Areata
dermatological_conditions.description: An autoimmune condition causing sudden, patchy hair loss on the scalp, face, or other areas of the body.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Well-defined, round or oval patches of complete hair loss with smooth, normal-appearing skin. The patches may be single or multiple. 'Exclamation point' hairs (short, broken hairs that are wider at the tip) may be visible at the edges of patches.
symptoms: Sudden onset of round, smooth patches of hair loss
Complete absence of hair in affected areas
Exclamation point hairs around patch borders
Possible progression to total scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis)
advice: Consider wigs or hairpieces for cosmetic coverage
Join support groups for emotional support
Maintain good overall health and manage stress
Be patient as hair regrowth can take months
Regular follow-up with dermatologist is important

dermatological_conditions.name: Androgenic Alopecia
dermatological_conditions.description: The most common form of hair loss in both men and women, caused by genetics and sensitivity to dihydrotestosterone (DHT).
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: In men: receding hairline and crown thinning progressing to complete baldness on top. In women: diffuse thinning over the crown while maintaining the frontal hairline. Hair appears progressively thinner and shorter over time.
symptoms: Gradual hair thinning over months to years
Diffuse thinning over the top of scalp (women)
advice: Start treatment early for best results
Maintain a healthy diet rich in protein

dermatological_conditions.name: Discoid Lupus
dermatological_conditions.description: A chronic autoimmune condition causing inflammatory skin lesions, typically on sun-exposed areas.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Well-defined, disc-shaped plaques with raised, red, scaly borders and central atrophy. Lesions may show hyperpigmentation or hypopigmentation. On the scalp, they cause scarring alopecia with permanent hair loss.
symptoms: Permanent hair loss when affecting scalp
advice: Strict sun protection with SPF 30+ sunscreen

dermatological_conditions.name: Dissecting Cellulitis
dermatological_conditions.description: A rare, chronic inflammatory condition of the scalp characterized by deep nodules and sinus tracts.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Deep, fluctuant nodules on the scalp that may rupture and form sinus tracts. The lesions appear as boggy, tender masses with possible purulent discharge. Significant scarring and permanent hair loss occur in affected areas.
advice: Consider psychological support for cosmetic concerns

dermatological_conditions.name: Folliculitis Decalvans
dermatological_conditions.description: A chronic inflammatory condition causing scarring alopecia with recurrent follicular pustules.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Patches of hair loss with follicular pustules and crusting. The affected areas show erythema, scaling, and eventually smooth scarring. Tufted hairs (multiple hair shafts emerging from single follicles) may be present.

dermatological_conditions.name: Hirsutism
dermatological_conditions.description: Excessive hair growth in women in areas where men typically grow hair, due to increased androgen levels.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Coarse, dark hair growth in male-pattern areas including face (upper lip, chin, cheeks), chest, back, abdomen, and inner thighs. The hair is terminal rather than vellus hair.
symptoms: Coarse hair on chest and back
Hair growth on abdomen and inner thighs
advice: Be patient as treatment takes several months

dermatological_conditions.name: Hot Comb Alopecia
dermatological_conditions.description: Hair loss caused by repeated use of hot combs, relaxers, or other heat styling tools, particularly common in African American women.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Patchy hair loss typically along the hairline and crown. The affected areas may show broken hair shafts, inflammation, and eventual scarring. The hair loss pattern follows areas of repeated heat application.
treatment: Discontinue heat styling and chemical treatments
advice: Avoid heat styling tools and chemical relaxers
Use heat protectant products if styling needed
Sleep on silk or satin pillowcases
Consult trichologist for hair care guidance

dermatological_conditions.name: Lichen Planopilaris
dermatological_conditions.description: An inflammatory condition causing scarring alopecia, considered the follicular variant of lichen planus.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Multifocal areas of hair loss with follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular erythema. The affected areas show scaling around hair follicles and eventual smooth scarring. Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a variant affecting the frontal hairline.
advice: Early treatment is crucial to prevent progression
Consider hair prosthetics for cosmetic coverage

dermatological_conditions.name: Pseudopelade
dermatological_conditions.description: A rare form of scarring alopecia characterized by smooth, atrophic patches of hair loss without inflammation.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Irregular, moth-eaten pattern of hair loss with smooth, white, atrophic areas. The patches have a characteristic 'footprints in the snow' appearance. There is no visible inflammation or scaling.
symptoms: Permanent hair loss in affected areas

dermatological_conditions.name: Telogen Effluvium
dermatological_conditions.description: A temporary form of hair loss caused by disruption of the hair growth cycle, often triggered by stress, illness, or medications.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Diffuse thinning of hair over the entire scalp without distinct bald patches. The scalp remains visible through thinned hair. Hair appears less dense overall, and increased shedding is noticeable.
symptoms: Hair loss 2-3 months after triggering event
advice: Be patient as recovery takes 6-12 months

dermatological_conditions.name: Trichorrhexis Nodosa
dermatological_conditions.description: A hair shaft defect characterized by weak points along the hair shaft that appear as nodes, leading to easy breakage.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Hair shafts show characteristic nodes or swellings that appear as white or light-colored bands across the hair. Under microscopy, the affected areas look like two brushes pushed together end-to-end.
treatment: Avoid chemical treatments and heat styling
advice: Use wide-tooth combs and soft brushes
Regular trimming to remove damaged ends

dermatological_conditions.name: Trichotillomania
dermatological_conditions.description: A psychiatric condition characterized by the compulsive urge to pull out one's own hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Irregular patches of hair loss with hairs of varying lengths. The affected areas show a 'moth-eaten' appearance with some completely bald spots and areas of shortened, stubby hair regrowth.
symptoms: Hairs of varying lengths in affected areas
advice: Identify triggers and early warning signs
Keep hands busy with alternative activities
Join support groups for shared experiences

dermatological_conditions.name: Tufted Folliculitis
dermatological_conditions.description: A rare form of folliculitis characterized by multiple hair shafts emerging from a single follicular opening, creating tufts of hair.
dermatological_conditions.image_appearance: Clusters of 10-20 hair shafts emerging from single, dilated follicular openings. The affected areas may show inflammation, crusting, and eventual scarring. The tufts create a distinctive appearance of bundled hair.
symptoms: Multiple hairs emerging from single follicles
